subtitles.text: Hello and welcome.
I'm James Murphy, and today we're talking about binary search.
Binary search, also called bisection search, is an algorithm for finding an element quickly in a sorted array.
Suppose we're trying to find 7 in this array.
Is it in the left half or the right half?
The right half.
And then repeat.
Finally, there's just one element left.
That's our 7.
Even though it's one of the first algorithms that one learns, it's also extremely important.
Analyzing binary search is often the branching point for studying things like time complexities of algorithms and big O notation.
Here you can see we started with 8 elements, and at each step we ruled out half of them.
This idea of ruling out half of all the possibilities at each step is where binary search or bisection search gets its name.
This is also where it gets its logarithmic time complexity from.
So binary search is useful, fundamental, and simple.
And yet a huge percentage of programmers, even professional programmers, struggle to write binary search.
How can the idea be so simple, but the implementation be so difficult?
Well, it's not so difficult.
You just have to think about it in the right way.
The first thing we should decide on is are we returning the object that we find or the index that it was at?
The index itself is a more useful piece of information.
We can always just grab the object at that index later.
But what do we do if the object we're looking for isn't there?
Do we do something like return negative one or maybe raise an exception?
Or what if there are multiple valid indices to choose from?
With every arbitrary choice that we make, we would have to remember the implementation details that go with that choice.
A better way to do it is to rephrase the question so that there is always exactly one answer.
So here's how I would rephrase the question.
If I were going to add another seven into this sorted array, where should I put it so that it's the first seven?
Notice that in this hypothetical, I'm always adding the seven into the array.
That guarantees the array is nonempty and always contains at least one seven.
But if it contains at least one seven, then there is always a unique first seven.
The index of that first seven is the answer to my question.
It doesn't matter whether or not the original array had a seven or multiple sevens in it.
The location of the first seven in the new array is always uniquely determined.
If there were no sevens, I would have to put it here to maintain the sorting property.
And if there are already sevens, it would have to be the index of the first already existing one.
Even if the array were empty, I still get a valid answer.
In this case, I would have to insert the seven at index zero.
Notice that zero is not a valid index into this array, but it still makes sense because the question that I asked was where should I insert it.
And it certainly makes sense to insert it at index zero.
The same applies for a nonempty array.
Binary search might tell me that I have to put it at the end.
As long as you keep in mind this interpretation of what binary search is supposed to return, it's much harder to get confused.
I think that far too often binary search is taught solely as an algorithm that works on sorted arrays.
But the array being sorted, I claim, is not actually the property that we're using here.
Here, look, I changed some of the elements and this array is no longer in sorted order.
But notice, the steps are exactly the same.
What we need is that everything less than seven is on the left and everything bigger than seven is on the right.
In this array, the numbers have been replaced with the important information.
Is this number less than seven?
Notice how any trues are on the left and any falses are on the right.
So now that we're looking at the relevant data, where do we insert seven so that it is the first seven?
Notice that the answer that we're looking for is the index of the first false value, or the end of the array if there are no false values.
This is the key insight that we need to keep in mind that makes the implementation extremely easy to remember.
Squint your eyes and find the first false value.
Okay, let's write the implementation.
Low and high are lower and upper bounds on where this first false index is.
Zero would mean the first value is false and length of the array would mean that all of the values are true, so we would need to put x at the end.
The idea is that we are going to continually increase our lower bound and decrease our upper bound until they're equal.
Low and high will meet at the unique index that we're looking for, so we could return either low or high.
It makes no difference.
We compute mid, which is the closest index to the middle between low and high.
Python can represent arbitrarily large integers so we don't need to worry about overflow, but if you're doing this in another language besides Python you might have to worry about overflow.
In that case you can represent the midpoint equivalently by writing it as low plus half the distance between low and high.
If you write it this way it will never overflow.
Next comes the part of the algorithm that is most often written incorrectly.
We need to compare whatever's in the array at the midpoint with our given x and then update the lower or upper bound accordingly.
Remember we're looking for the first false value where true or false is determined by asking the question, is this less than x?
Well in this section the middle value is less than x.
It is a true value.
Since the value at mid is a true value the earliest a false value could occur is the next one, which is mid plus one.
What about if we see a false value?
In this case the first false value couldn't be any later than mid because there is a false value at mid, but it could be earlier.
There might be other false values before the one that we've found.
That means the best we can do is update our upper bound to be whatever mid is.
And there you have it.
This is a correct implementation.
But how can we reason about it?
How do we know that this actually gives the right answer?

Well we know that low is always less than or equal to the correct answer is always less than or equal to high, and we do keep updating the lower and higher bounds, but how do we know that they actually meet so that the loop stops?
It's enough to show that every iteration the difference between high and low always decreases by at least one.
If we enter this clause the plus one ensures that low always increases by at least one.
In this clause we're setting high to mid, so hopefully we're lowering high, but how do we know that mid was actually strictly less than high?
Here we're actually using that integer division rounds down.
Inside the while loop low is less than high, so low plus high is strictly less than high plus high.
That means that when we divide by two and round down we'll get something strictly less than high.
It's common to take low and high as optional parameters so that if you already have a lower or upper bound you can make use of that.
And of course don't forget to check that the parameters are valid.
And that's all there is to it.
But wait, you ask, instead of returning the index to insert a 7 so that it would be the first 7, couldn't I also return the index so that it would be the last 7?
Yeah, you could.
You could follow essentially the same analysis and get a very similar algorithm.
To find where it should go to be the first 7, the relevant piece of information is, is it strictly less than 7?
To find where it should go to be the last 7, you want to know is it less than or equal to 7?
In either case, the index that you're looking for is the first false value.
You just need to decide on what you mean by true and false.
The first one is called bisect left and the second bisect right.
So this one that we already wrote is bisect left.
Can you tell me what you need to change in order to make it bisect right?
Here's an example of how you might use bisect left.
For this function, we want to find the index of the first x in the array or throw an error if there isn't one.
Since we're looking for the first index, we'll use bisect left.
If there is already an x in the array, bisect left will return the index of the first one.
So we would like to just check at that index and see if we see an x.
If we don't get back a valid index, or if we find that there is not an x at the location that bisect left told us to look at, then there's no x in the array, so we raise an error.
The last thing that I want to mention is that the bisect library in Python already has bisect left and bisect right implemented for you.
So if you need to do a bisection, prefer using the builtin Python bisect library.
You don't need to install anything in order to use it.
That's all I have for today.
I hope this helped you understand binary search a little bit better.
If you like this video, please consider subscribing.
And as always, don't forget to slap that like button an odd number of times.

steps.description: Introduce the concept of binary search, explaining its purpose, importance, and intuitive nature using relatable examples. Highlight the necessity of a sorted array for binary search to work effectively.
steps.instructions: Explain what binary search is and how it works by dividing a sorted array into halves to find an element quickly. Use examples to illustrate the process.
steps.explanations: Binary search is a fundamental algorithm that is important for understanding time complexities and big O notation. It works by repeatedly dividing a sorted array in half to locate an element, which is efficient due to its logarithmic time complexity.
steps.tips: Think of binary search as a process of elimination where you rule out half of the possibilities at each step, which is why it is efficient.
steps.warnings: Binary search requires a sorted array to function correctly. If the array is not sorted, the algorithm will not work as intended.

materials.caption: A photo of a sorted integer array.
materials.description: A sorted integer array is used as the input for the binary search algorithm. The array must be sorted for the binary search to work correctly, as the algorithm relies on the order of elements to efficiently find the target value.

tools.caption: A diagram illustrating the binary search algorithm process.
tools.description: The binary search algorithm is a method for finding a target value within a sorted array. It works by repeatedly dividing the search interval in half, comparing the target value to the middle element of the array, and narrowing down the search to the half where the target value is likely to be.

outcomes.caption: A photo showing the index of the target value in the array.
outcomes.description: The outcome of the binary search is the index of the target value in the sorted array. If the target value is not present, the algorithm can be designed to return a special value, such as -1, or raise an exception.

steps.description: Explain the basic concept of binary search and its importance in computer science.
steps.instructions: Introduce binary search as an algorithm for finding an element quickly in a sorted array.
steps.explanations: Binary search is fundamental because it efficiently finds elements in logarithmic time, making it a crucial algorithm in computer science.
steps.tips: Remember that binary search is also known as bisection search.
steps.warnings: Ensure the array is sorted before applying binary search, as the algorithm relies on this property.

steps.description: Demonstrate the binary search process using an example with a sorted integer array.
steps.instructions: Use a sorted array and a target value to show how binary search divides the array and rules out half of the elements at each step.
steps.explanations: Binary search works by comparing the target value to the middle element of the array, then narrowing the search to the half where the target value is likely to be. This process is repeated until the target value is found or the search interval is empty.
steps.tips: Visualize the array division process to better understand how binary search narrows down the search space.
steps.warnings: If the array is not sorted, binary search will not work correctly.

steps.description: Discuss the implementation details and considerations for binary search.
steps.instructions: Consider what to return if the target value is not found and how to handle multiple occurrences of the target value.
steps.explanations: Deciding on the return value for binary search is important for handling cases where the target value is not present. Rephrasing the problem to always have a unique answer simplifies the implementation.
steps.tips: Rephrase the problem to ensure there is always a unique answer, which simplifies the implementation.
steps.warnings: Consider edge cases such as an empty array or multiple occurrences of the target value.

steps.description: Decide on the return value of the binary search function, whether it should return the index of the found element or the element itself.
steps.instructions: Determine if the function should return the index of the found element or the element itself. Returning the index is more useful.
steps.explanations: Returning the index is more useful because you can always retrieve the element using the index later.

steps.description: Rephrase the binary search problem to ensure a unique answer by considering where to insert an element to maintain sorted order.
steps.instructions: Rephrase the problem to find the index where an element should be inserted to maintain sorted order, ensuring a unique answer.
steps.explanations: Rephrasing the problem ensures that there is always a unique answer, even if the element is not present in the array.

steps.description: Implement the binary search algorithm using a loop to iteratively find the correct index.
steps.instructions: Use a loop to iteratively adjust the lower and upper bounds until they converge on the correct index.
steps.explanations: The loop continues until the lower and upper bounds converge, ensuring the correct index is found. The midpoint calculation avoids overflow issues.
steps.tips: Use integer division to avoid overflow when calculating the midpoint.
steps.warnings: Ensure that the midpoint calculation does not overflow, especially in languages other than Python.

steps.description: Implement the recursive version of binary search by defining the base case and recursive case.
Modify the binary search to find the last occurrence of an element by adjusting the comparison logic.
steps.instructions: Adjust the comparison logic to find the last occurrence of an element by checking if elements are less than or equal to the target.
steps.explanations: Finding the last occurrence requires checking if elements are less than or equal to the target, which changes the definition of true and false in the search.

steps.description: Discuss the importance of understanding the problem correctly when implementing binary search.
steps.instructions: Rephrase the problem to ensure there is always exactly one answer, such as determining where to insert an element to maintain order.
steps.explanations: By rephrasing the problem, you ensure that the implementation has a clear and unique goal, which simplifies reasoning about correctness.
steps.tips: Think about the problem in terms of maintaining order and finding a unique position for insertion.
steps.warnings: Avoid arbitrary choices that can lead to confusion and errors in implementation.

steps.description: Ensure bounds converge correctly in the binary search implementation.
steps.instructions: Use a loop to adjust the lower and upper bounds until they converge to a single point.
steps.explanations: The bounds converge because each iteration reduces the difference between them by at least one, ensuring the loop will eventually terminate.
steps.tips: Use integer division to avoid overflow and ensure correct midpoint calculation.
steps.warnings: Be careful with the midpoint calculation to avoid infinite loops or incorrect results.

steps.description: Reason about the correctness of the binary search implementation.
steps.instructions: Verify that the loop invariants hold and that the bounds are updated correctly in each iteration.
steps.explanations: The correctness is ensured by maintaining the invariant that the target index is always between the current bounds, and by reducing the bounds until they meet.
steps.tips: Check that each update to the bounds is justified by the comparison at the midpoint.
steps.warnings: Ensure that the loop conditions and updates do not violate the invariant or lead to incorrect results.

outcomes.caption: A photo of a sorted array with an insertion point marked.
outcomes.description: The unique index where an element should be inserted to maintain the sorted order of the array, ensuring a consistent outcome for the binary search problem.

steps.description: Decide whether to return the index of the element or handle cases where the element is not found.
steps.instructions: Determine if the binary search should return the index of the found element or handle the case where the element is not present by returning a special value like -1 or raising an exception.
steps.explanations: Returning the index is more useful because you can retrieve the element later. Handling the case where the element is not found is necessary to avoid errors.
steps.tips: Consider how you will handle multiple valid indices or the absence of the element to ensure consistent implementation.
steps.warnings: Arbitrary choices in handling not found cases can lead to confusion and errors in implementation.

steps.description: Rephrase the binary search problem to ensure a unique solution.
steps.instructions: Reframe the problem to always have a unique answer by determining where to insert an element to maintain order.
steps.explanations: By rephrasing the problem to find the insertion point, you ensure that there is always a unique solution, even if the element is not originally in the array.
steps.tips: Think of the problem as finding the first position where the element could be inserted to maintain sorted order.
steps.warnings: Ensure that the rephrased problem accounts for all edge cases, such as empty arrays or arrays without the element.

steps.description: Clarify the properties needed for binary search, emphasizing the arrangement of elements rather than strict sorting.
steps.instructions: Understand that binary search requires the array to be arranged such that all elements less than the target are on the left and all elements greater than the target are on the right.
steps.explanations: The array does not need to be strictly sorted; it only needs to have elements arranged in a way that allows binary search to function correctly. This means that elements less than the target should be on the left, and elements greater than the target should be on the right.
steps.tips: Focus on the logical arrangement of elements rather than their exact order.
steps.warnings: Do not assume that the array must be sorted in the traditional sense; it only needs to meet the condition of having all lesser elements on the left and greater elements on the right.

steps.description: Discuss the use of optional parameters for bounds and the importance of validating input parameters.
steps.instructions: Consider using optional parameters for the lower and upper bounds in the binary search function to allow flexibility in specifying the search range.
steps.explanations: Optional parameters for bounds can be useful if you already have a specific range within the array that you want to search. This can make the function more versatile and reusable.
steps.tips: Use optional parameters to make your function more flexible and adaptable to different use cases.
steps.warnings: Ensure that the parameters provided are valid to avoid errors during the execution of the binary search.

tools.caption: A photo of a computer screen displaying the Python bisect library documentation.
tools.description: The Python bisect library provides functions for maintaining a list in sorted order without having to sort the list repeatedly. It includes functions like bisect_left and bisect_right, which are used to perform binary search operations efficiently.

steps.description: Explore variations of binary search, such as finding the first or last occurrence of an element, and the concept of bisect left and right.
steps.instructions: To find the first occurrence of an element, use the bisect left approach, which checks if elements are strictly less than the target. For the last occurrence, use bisect right, which checks if elements are less than or equal to the target.
steps.explanations: The bisect left approach helps find the first position where an element can be inserted to maintain sorted order, while bisect right finds the last position. These variations are useful for different search requirements.
steps.tips: Decide on what you mean by true and false for your specific use case to choose between bisect left and bisect right.

steps.description: Introduce the Python bisect library as a tool for implementing binary search efficiently and correctly.
steps.instructions: Use the Python bisect library for binary search operations to avoid implementing the algorithm from scratch. It provides built-in functions like bisect_left and bisect_right.
steps.explanations: The bisect library is efficient and reduces the chance of errors in implementing binary search manually. It is part of Python's standard library, so no additional installation is required.
steps.tips: Prefer using the built-in bisect library functions for binary search tasks to ensure correctness and efficiency.
steps.warnings: Ensure you understand the difference between bisect_left and bisect_right to use them correctly for your specific needs.

steps.description: Summarize the key points of the binary search implementation and its applications.
steps.instructions: Summarize the binary search implementations and encourage applying the algorithm to other data types, emphasizing the requirement for sorted data.
steps.explanations: The tutorial aimed to help viewers understand binary search better, highlighting its importance and applications.

steps.instructions: Encourage viewers to engage with the content by subscribing or liking the video.

subtitles.text: Hi, I'm Gail LockeMcDowell, author of Cracking Coding Interview.
Today I'm going to cover binary search.
So binary search is a very intuitive algorithm and I'm going to show how intuitive it is by giving an example.

You're a teacher and you're teaching a group of students, a very large class of 300 students, and you have their papers alphabetized out in front of you when a student, Zach Peters, comes up to get his paper back.
So you probably wouldn't go through the papers, starting with Alex to Andy to Andrew and then to Bob and Brenda and Brandy and then to Chris and Christine and you probably wouldn't do it that way.
What you'd probably do is open the stack of papers to roughly halfway through the papers and compare it.
Zach Peters, well, you open up halfway through and you see Michael Matters there and you'd say, okay, Zach Peters is after that name.
And then you take the second stack of papers and you'd treat it as its own little stack and you'd again say, okay, let me open up to its midpoint.
Maybe we see Sarah.
Well, is Sarah before or after Zach Peters?
And then you just go and repeat this process over and over and over again until you find Zach's paper or until you find out Zach can't be in here.
And this is the basics of binary search.
So in an integer array it looks like this.
You take some element that you're looking for, like 13, and you compare it to the midpoint.
And it has to be a sorted array for this to work.
It's very important.
And you compare it to the midpoint.
13 is less than this midpoint and so 13, if it's in the array at all, it has to be on the left side.
And then you'd repeat this process on the left side and say, let me look at the midpoint of the left side.
Is 13 before and after that?
Before or after that?
And you just repeat that process until you either find 13 or you know that 13 can't be in it.
So how fast is this algorithm?
Well, let's imagine we start off with n elements.
So we have a search space of n elements.
In a single comparison, just one, we've cut our search space down to n over 2.
Then with one more comparison we cut it down to n over 4.
And then and half again and half and half and half and half again.
So how many total operations, in the very worst case, will we have to run until we figure out if it contains an element or not?
Well, the total number of operations we'll have to do is determined by how many times can we divide n by 2 until we get down to just 1.
So this is what log of n expresses, or log base 2 of n expresses.
So if you pause the video you can study that math for a second and see the relationship between those two things.
But this means that binary search is a log n problem.
Let's look now at the implementation of binary search.
To implement binary search we can either implement it recursively or iteratively.
We'll do a recursive implementation first.
So I'm going to just copy and paste here some just straightforward code for the binary search call.
So this is a initial method that calls off to this binary search recursive method with the right parameters.
So we're going to start off initially with left being 0 and right being the very right point.
So these are inclusive endpoints.
So first of all, if things get kind of too big, if left winds up bigger than right, then we know we have an error, we can't find it, and we want to return true.
Otherwise we want to pick the midpoint, so left dot right divided by 2, that's going to be the midpoint.
And if we found the element, if array of mid is actually this element we're looking for, then we should return true.
Otherwise if x is on the left side of mid, then go search the left side.
So pass an array x and left will stay as is and the right point will move to one next to the mid.
Otherwise go search the right side.
So we want to call a very similar method, but now the left point moves up to mid plus 1 and right stays as is.
Okay, so that's how the binary search recursive implementation looks.
So one little minor pitfall is that, and some people like to be careful of it, is that left plus right can actually overflow with java integers.
So if you'd like to avoid the integer overflow issue, you can actually just do this instead and this will prevent the overflow.
It's kind of up to you, but this is one way of doing it.
Okay, so now that we've done the recursive implementation, let's turn to the iterative implementation.
So what I'm going to do is I'm going to actually tweak this recursive implementation.
I'm going to copy paste it into a new function and I'm going to tweak it to make it iterative.
So I'm going to call this iterative and I no longer need parameters in here, but what I'm going to do is I'm going to set, so I'm going to show you how you can tweak it.
So I'm going to set left to be that right is going to start off at the rightmost position in the array.
So now I want to iterate as long, I want to loop through this as long as left and right are such in the correct positions.
So change this to a while loop.
Alright, and then if I exit here then I haven't found it.
Okay, so this looks correct and then here I don't want to actually recurse anymore.
What I want to do is essentially take these values here.
So left is going to stay as is and right is going to move to mid minus one.
I'm going to comment that out and I'll delete it shortly.
And then here rather than, so left is going to stay, or left is going to become mid plus one and right is going to stay as is.
So that's how easy it is to tweak it from recursive to iterative.
So that's how we implement binary search.
Now remember that it can be implemented recursively or iteratively and it can also be applied to other data like strings or something else, but it must always operate on something that's sorted.
So now that you've seen the implementation of binary search, why don't you try to do binary search on a new data type like a string.
Good luck!

original_subgoals.title: Introduction
original_subgoals.description: Introduce the concept of binary search and its intuitive nature using a relatable example.
original_subgoals.text: Hi, I'm Gail LockeMcDowell, author of Cracking Coding Interview. Today I'm going to cover binary search. So binary search is a very intuitive algorithm and I'm going to show how intuitive it is by giving an example. You're a teacher and you're teaching a group of students, a very large class of 300 students, and you have their papers alphabetized out in front of you when a student, Zach Peters, comes up to get his paper back. So you probably wouldn't go through the papers, starting with Alex to Andy to Andrew and then to Bob and Brenda and Brandy and then to Chris and Christine and you probably wouldn't do it that way. What you'd probably do is open the stack of papers to roughly halfway through the papers and compare it. Zach Peters, well, you open up halfway through and you see Michael Matters there and you'd say, okay, Zach Peters is after that name. And then you take the second stack of papers and you'd treat it as its own little stack and you'd again say, okay, let me open up to its midpoint. Maybe we see Sarah. Well, is Sarah before or after Zach Peters? And then you just go and repeat this process over and over and over again until you find Zach's paper or until you find out Zach can't be in here. And this is the basics of binary search.

subgoals.title: Binary Search Explanation-1
subgoals.description: Explain the basic concept and step-by-step process of binary search using an example with a sorted integer array. Emphasize the importance of the array being sorted and how the algorithm divides the array, ruling out half of the elements at each step.
subgoals.text: So in an integer array it looks like this. You take some element that you're looking for, like 13, and you compare it to the midpoint. And it has to be a sorted array for this to work. It's very important. And you compare it to the midpoint. 13 is less than this midpoint and so 13, if it's in the array at all, it has to be on the left side. And then you'd repeat this process on the left side and say, let me look at the midpoint of the left side. Is 13 before and after that? Before or after that? And you just repeat that process until you either find 13 or you know that 13 can't be in it.

And you just repeat that process until you either find 13 or you know that 13 can't be in it.

subgoals.title: Algorithm Efficiency-2
subgoals.description: Discuss the efficiency of the binary search algorithm, explaining how it reduces the search space and operates in logarithmic time complexity.
subgoals.text: So how fast is this algorithm? Well, let's imagine we start off with n elements. So we have a search space of n elements. In a single comparison, just one, we've cut our search space down to n over 2. Then with one more comparison we cut it down to n over 4. And then and half again and half and half and half and half again. So how many total operations, in the very worst case, will we have to run until we figure out if it contains an element or not? Well, the total number of operations we'll have to do is determined by how many times can we divide n by 2 until we get down to just 1. So this is what log of n expresses, or log base 2 of n expresses. So if you pause the video you can study that math for a second and see the relationship between those two things. But this means that binary search is a log n problem.

subgoals.title: Implementation Methods-3
subgoals.description: Describe how to implement binary search both recursively and iteratively. Include the base case and recursive case logic for the recursive implementation, and explain how to modify this approach to use a loop for the iterative implementation.
subgoals.text: Let's look now at the implementation of binary search. To implement binary search we can either implement it recursively or iteratively. We'll do a recursive implementation first. So I'm going to just copy and paste here some just straightforward code for the binary search call. So this is a initial method that calls off to this binary search recursive method with the right parameters. So we're going to start off initially with left being 0 and right being the very right point. So these are inclusive endpoints. So first of all, if things get kind of too big, if left winds up bigger than right, then we know we have an error, we can't find it, and we want to return true. Otherwise we want to pick the midpoint, so left dot right divided by 2, that's going to be the midpoint. And if we found the element, if array of mid is actually this element we're looking for, then we should return true. Otherwise if x is on the left side of mid, then go search the left side. So pass an array x and left will stay as is and the right point will move to one next to the mid. Otherwise go search the right side. So we want to call a very similar method, but now the left point moves up to mid plus 1 and right stays as is. Okay, so that's how the binary search recursive implementation looks. So one little minor pitfall is that, and some people like to be careful of it, is that left plus right can actually overflow with java integers. So if you'd like to avoid the integer overflow issue, you can actually just do this instead and this will prevent the overflow. It's kind of up to you, but this is one way of doing it. Okay, so now that we've done the recursive implementation, let's turn to the iterative implementation. So what I'm going to do is I'm going to actually tweak this recursive implementation. I'm going to copy paste it into a new function and I'm going to tweak it to make it iterative. So I'm going to call this iterative and I no longer need parameters in here, but what I'm going to do is I'm going to set, so I'm going to show you how you can tweak it. So I'm going to set left to be that right is going to start off at the rightmost position in the array. So now I want to iterate as long, I want to loop through this as long as left and right are such in the correct positions. So change this to a while loop. Alright, and then if I exit here then I haven't found it. Okay, so this looks correct and then here I don't want to actually recurse anymore. What I want to do is essentially take these values here. So left is going to stay as is and right is going to move to mid minus one. I'm going to comment that out and I'll delete it shortly. And then here rather than, so left is going to stay, or left is going to become mid plus one and right is going to stay as is. So that's how easy it is to tweak it from recursive to iterative.

subgoals.title: Conclusion-4
subgoals.description: Summarize the binary search implementations and encourage applying the algorithm to other data types, emphasizing the requirement for sorted data. Conclude the tutorial with a summary and encourage viewers to engage with the content by subscribing or liking the video.
subgoals.text: So that's how we implement binary search. Now remember that it can be implemented recursively or iteratively and it can also be applied to other data like strings or something else, but it must always operate on something that's sorted. So now that you've seen the implementation of binary search, why don't you try to do binary search on a new data type like a string. Good luck!

outcomes.description: The viewer gains an understanding of the binary search algorithm, its purpose, and how it operates on a sorted array.

steps.description: Introduce the concept of binary search using a relatable example of searching for a student's paper in a stack of alphabetized papers.
steps.instructions: Imagine you are a teacher with a stack of 300 alphabetized student papers, and a student named Zach Peters comes to retrieve his paper. Instead of searching sequentially, you open the stack to the midpoint and compare.
steps.explanations: This example demonstrates the intuitive nature of binary search by showing how it efficiently narrows down the search space by repeatedly dividing it in half.
steps.tips: Think of binary search as a way to quickly zero in on the target by eliminating half of the remaining possibilities with each step.
steps.warnings: Ensure the papers (or array) are sorted; otherwise, binary search will not work correctly.

steps.description: Explain the necessity of a sorted array for binary search to work effectively.
steps.instructions: Highlight that binary search requires the array to be sorted to function correctly.
steps.explanations: Binary search relies on the ability to eliminate half of the search space based on comparisons, which only works if the data is sorted.
steps.tips: Always check or sort your data before applying binary search to ensure it operates correctly.
steps.warnings: Attempting binary search on an unsorted array will lead to incorrect results.

materials.caption: A photo of a sorted integer array.
materials.description: A sorted integer array is essential for binary search to work. The array must be sorted in ascending order to ensure that the algorithm can correctly determine which half of the array to discard at each step.

outcomes.caption: A diagram illustrating the binary search process on a sorted array.
outcomes.description: The viewer will understand the binary search algorithm, including how it divides the array and rules out half of the elements at each step, and why it is important for the array to be sorted.

steps.description: Introduce the concept of binary search using a real-world analogy of searching for a student's paper in a stack of alphabetized papers.
steps.instructions: Imagine you are searching for a student's paper in a stack of alphabetized papers. Instead of going through each paper one by one, you open the stack to the midpoint and compare.
steps.explanations: This analogy helps to illustrate the efficiency of binary search by showing how it eliminates half of the search space with each comparison.
steps.tips: Think of binary search as a way to quickly narrow down the search space by repeatedly dividing it in half.
steps.warnings: Ensure the papers (or array) are sorted; otherwise, binary search will not work correctly.

steps.description: Explain the binary search process on a sorted integer array.
steps.instructions: Take an element you are searching for, like 13, and compare it to the midpoint of the array. If 13 is less than the midpoint, search the left half; otherwise, search the right half.
steps.explanations: Binary search works by repeatedly dividing the array in half and discarding the half that cannot contain the target element. This is why the array must be sorted.
steps.tips: Visualize the array as a series of steps, where each step involves checking the midpoint and deciding which half to discard.
steps.warnings: The array must be sorted for binary search to function correctly. If the array is not sorted, the algorithm will not be able to correctly determine which half to discard.

steps.description: Discuss the efficiency of the binary search algorithm by explaining how it reduces the search space and operates in logarithmic time complexity.
steps.instructions: Explain how binary search reduces the search space by half with each comparison and operates in logarithmic time complexity.
steps.explanations: Binary search starts with a search space of n elements. With each comparison, it reduces the search space by half, first to n/2, then to n/4, and so on. The number of operations required is determined by how many times n can be divided by 2 until it reaches 1, which is expressed as log base 2 of n. This means binary search has a time complexity of O(log n).

steps.description: Implement the recursive version of binary search.
steps.instructions: Start with a method that calls the recursive binary search function with the initial parameters: left as 0 and right as the last index of the array. Check if left is greater than right, which means the element is not found, and return false. Calculate the midpoint as (left + right) / 2. If the element at the midpoint is the target, return true. If the target is less than the element at the midpoint, recursively search the left half by adjusting the right boundary. Otherwise, recursively search the right half by adjusting the left boundary.
steps.explanations: The recursive approach divides the array into halves and searches in the half where the target could be, based on comparison with the midpoint. This continues until the target is found or the search space is exhausted.
steps.tips: To avoid integer overflow when calculating the midpoint, use left + (right - left) / 2 instead of (left + right) / 2.
steps.warnings: Ensure that the array is sorted before performing binary search, as the algorithm assumes a sorted array.

steps.description: Convert the recursive binary search implementation to an iterative version.
steps.instructions: Copy the recursive function and modify it to use a loop instead of recursion. Initialize left and right as before. Use a while loop to iterate as long as left is less than or equal to right. Calculate the midpoint inside the loop. If the element at the midpoint is the target, return true. If the target is less than the element at the midpoint, adjust the right boundary to mid - 1. Otherwise, adjust the left boundary to mid + 1. If the loop exits without finding the target, return false.
steps.explanations: The iterative approach uses a loop to repeatedly narrow down the search space, which can be more efficient in terms of memory usage compared to recursion.

steps.description: Summarize the key points of binary search implementation and its applications.
steps.instructions: Summarize the binary search implementations and encourage applying the algorithm to other data types, emphasizing the requirement for sorted data.
steps.explanations: Binary search can be implemented both recursively and iteratively. It is a versatile algorithm that can be applied to various data types, such as strings, as long as the data is sorted.
steps.tips: Try implementing binary search on different data types to understand its versatility.
steps.warnings: Ensure that the data is sorted before applying binary search, as it only works on sorted data.
